{{distinguish|Higher Education (journal){{!}}the academic journal|Higher Education (novel){{!}}the novel}} {{redirect|Higher learning||Higher Learning (disambiguation)}} {{Globalize/US|date=June 2018}} {{Broader|Tertiary education}} [[File:Var 132.jpg|right|thumb|[[University of al-Qarawiyyin|The University of al-Qarawiyyin]] in [[Fez, Morocco]] is the world's oldest existing, continually operating and the first degree awarding institution of higher learning in the world according to [[UNESCO]] and [[Guinness World Records]].<ref>[http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/3000/oldest-university Oldest University]</ref><ref>Verger, Jacques: "Patterns", in: Ridder-Symoens, Hilde de (ed.): ''A History of the University in Europe. Vol. I: Universities in the Middle Ages'', Cambridge University Press, 2003, {{ISBN|978-0-521-54113-8}}, pp. 35–76 (35)</ref>]] [[File:Bologna-vista02.jpg|right|thumb|[[University of Bologna]], located in [[Bologna, Italy]], is the oldest institution of higher education in the [[Western world]].<ref>[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/2017/world-ranking#!/page/0/length/25/sort_by/rank/sort_order/asc/cols/stats Top Universities] ''World University Rankings'' Retrieved 2010-1-6</ref><ref>[http://www.eng.unibo.it/PortaleEn/University/Our+History/default.htm Our History] - Università di Bologna</ref><ref>{{cite book | title=[https://books.google.com/books?id=wyjnHZ1IIlgC&pg=PA18&dq=the+oldest+university+in+the+world+Bologna&hl=en&ei=lFy-TtitBY3RrQflnNnjAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=the%20oldest%20university%20in%20the%20world%20Bologna&f=false The Challenge of Bologna]| author=Paul L. Gaston | year=2010 | pages=18 | isbn=978-1-57922-366-3}}</ref>]] [[File:College Hall U Penn.JPG|thumb|The [[University of Pennsylvania]] considers itself the first institution in the [[United States of America]] to use the term "university" in its name.]] [[File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg|right|thumb|The [[University of Cambridge]] is an institution of higher learning in [[Cambridge]], [[United Kingdom]].]] [[File:McGill University Arts Building2.JPG|right|thumb|[[McGill University]] is an institution of higher learning in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada and one of two Canadian members of the [[Association of American Universities]].]] [[File:Moskva MGU 3.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Moscow State University]] is an institution of higher learning in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]].]] [[File:Tsinghua University - Grand auditorium.JPG|alt=|thumb|The [[Jeffersonian architecture]] of [[Tsinghua University]], an institution of higher learning in [[Beijing]], [[China]].]] [[File:University of Tokyo - Gogetsusai 2010.JPG|right|thumb|The [[University of Tokyo]] is an institution of higher learning in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]].]] [[File:Faculdade de Direito da USP.jpg|right|thumb|The [[University of São Paulo]] is an institution of higher learning in [[São Paulo]], [[Brazil]].]] [[File:NOLA Experience (3853268761).jpg|thumb|Students of a U.S. university with their professor on extreme right, 2009]] '''Higher education''' (also called post-secondary education, third-level or [[tertiary education]]) is an optional final stage of [[formal learning]] that occurs after completion of [[secondary education]]. Often delivered at [[University|universities]], [[Academy|academies]], [[college]]s, [[seminary|seminaries]], [[school of music|conservatories]], and [[institute of technology|institutes of technology]], higher education is also available through certain college-level institutions, including [[vocational school]]s, trade schools, and other career colleges that award [[academic degree]]s or [[professional certification]]s. [[Tertiary education]] at non-degree level is sometimes referred to as [[further education]] or [[continuing education]] as distinct from higher education. The right of access to higher education is mentioned in a number of [[international human rights instruments]]. The [[United Nations|UN]] [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] of 1966 declares, in Article 13, that "higher education shall be made equally accessible to all, on the basis of capacity, by every appropriate means, and in particular by the progressive introduction of free education". In [[Europe]], Article 2 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights|First Protocol to the European Convention on Human Rights]], adopted in 1950, obliges all signatory parties to guarantee the [[right to education]].
In the days when few pupils progressed beyond [[primary education]] or [[basic education]], the term "higher education" was often used to refer to secondary education, which can create some confusion.<ref>For example, ''Higher Education: General and Technical'', a 1933 [[National Union of Teachers]] pamphlet by [[Lord Eustace Percy]], which is actually about secondary education and uses the two terms interchangeably.</ref> This is the origin of the term ''[[High school (North America)|high school]]'' for various schools for children between the ages of 14 and 18 (United States) or 11 and 18 (UK and Australia).<ref>[http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/high-school?a=british ]</ref>
[[File:RupertI.jpg|thumb|upright=0.5|[[Rupert I, Elector Palatine|Rupert I]] founded the [[University of Heidelberg]] in 1386]] Higher education includes teaching, research, exacting applied work (e.g. in [[medical school]]s and [[dental school]]s), and social services activities of universities.<ref>Pucciarelli F., Kaplan Andreas M. (2016) Competition and Strategy in Higher Education: Managing Complexity and Uncertainty, Business Horizons, Volume 59</ref> Within the realm of teaching, it includes both the ''[[undergraduate education|undergraduate]]'' level, and beyond that, ''[[Postgraduate education|graduate-level]]'' (or ''postgraduate'' level). The latter level of education is often referred to as [[graduate school]], especially in North America. In addition to the skills that are specific to any particular degree, potential employers in any profession are looking for evidence of [[critical thinking]] and [[analytical reasoning]] skills, [[teamwork]]ing skills, [[information literacy]], [[Ethics|ethical]] judgment, [[decision-making]] skills, fluency in speaking and writing, [[problem solving]] skills, and a wide knowledge of liberal arts and sciences.<ref>{{cite press release |last= |first= |date= 20 January 2015 |title= Employers Judge Recent Graduates Ill-Prepared for Today’s Workplace, Endorse Broad and Project-Based Learning as Best Preparation for Career Opportunity and Long-Term Success |url= http://www.aacu.org/press/press-releases/2015employerstudentsurveys |location= Washington, DC |publisher= [[Association of American Colleges and Universities]] |agency= |access-date=11 April 2017}}</ref>
Since [[World War II]], developed and many developing countries have increased the participation of the age group who mostly studies higher education from the elite rate, of up to 15 per cent, to the mass rate of 16 to 50 per cent.<ref>Trow, Martin (1973) Problems in the transition from elite to mass higher education. Carnegie Commission on Higher Education, Berkeley, http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=ED091983&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=ED091983, accessed 1 August 2013</ref><ref>Brennan, John (2004) The social role of the contemporary university: contradictions, boundaries and change, in Center for Higher Education Research and Information (ed.)</ref><ref>Ten years on: changing education in a changing world (Buckingham: The Open University Press), https://www.open.ac.uk/cheri/documents/ten-years-on.pdf, accessed 9 February 2014</ref> In many developed countries, participation in higher education has continued to increase towards universal or, what Trow later called, open access, where over half of the relevant age group participate in higher education.<ref>Trow, Martin (2007) [2005] Reflections on the transition from elite to mass to universal access: forms and phases of higher education in modern societies since WWII, Springer International Handbooks of Education volume 18, 2007, 243-280</ref> Higher education is important to national [[economy|economies]], both as an industry, in its own right, and as a source of trained and educated personnel for the rest of the economy. College educated workers have commanded a measurable wage premium and are much less likely to become unemployed than less educated workers.<ref name="Simkovic">{{cite journal |ssrn=1941070 | title=Risk-Based Student Loans| date=2011-09-05}}</ref><ref name = OECD>OECD, Education at a Glance (2011)</ref> However, the admission of so many students of only average ability to higher education inevitably requires a decline in [[academic standards]], facilitated by [[grade inflation]].<ref>{{Citation| last =Cote| first =James| last2 =Allahar| first2 =Anton| title =Ivory Tower Blues: A University System in Crisis| publisher =[[University of Toronto Press]]| year =2007| pages =256| isbn =978-0802091826}}</ref><ref>{{Citation| last =Arum| first =Richard| last2 =Roska| first2 =Josipa| title =Academically Adrift: Limited Learning on College Campuses| publisher =[[University of Chicago Press]]| year =2011| pages =272| isbn =978-0226028569}}</ref> Also, the supply of graduates in many fields of study is exceeding the demand for their skills, which aggravates [[graduate unemployment]], [[underemployment]], [[credentialism and educational inflation]].<ref>{{cite web| last =Barshay| first =Jill| title =Reflections on the underemployment of college graduates| website =Hechniger Report| publisher =Teachers College at Columbia University| date =4 August 2014| url =http://educationbythenumbers.org/content/underemployment-college-grads_1589/| accessdate = 30 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Citation| last =Coates| first =Ken| last2 =Morrison| first2 =Bill| author2-link =| title =Dream Factories: Why Universities Won't Solve the Youth Jobs Crisis| place =Toronto| publisher =Dundurn Press| year =2016| pages =232| url =https://www.dundurn.com/books/Dream-Factories| isbn =978-1459733770 }}</ref>
== History == {{main|History of higher education in the United States}} The U.S. system of higher education was heavily influenced by the [[Humboldtian model of higher education]]. [[Wilhelm von Humboldt]]'s educational model goes beyond vocational training. In a letter to the Prussian king, he wrote:
{{quote|There are undeniably certain kinds of knowledge that must be of a general nature and, more importantly, a certain cultivation of the mind and character that nobody can afford to be without. People obviously cannot be good craftworkers, merchants, soldiers or businessmen unless, regardless of their occupation, they are good, upstanding and – according to their condition – well-informed human beings and citizens. If this basis is laid through schooling, vocational skills are easily acquired later on, and a person is always free to move from one occupation to another, as so often happens in life.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1007/BF02192965|title=Profiles of educators: Wilhelm von Humboldt (1767–1835)|journal=Prospects|volume=18|pages=127–136|year=1988|last1=Günther|first1=Karl-Heinz}}</ref>}}
The philosopher [[Julian Nida-Rümelin]] criticized discrepancies between Humboldt's ideals and the contemporary European education policy, which narrowly understands education as a preparation for the labor market, and argued that we need to decide between [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey]] and Humboldt.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/2009/45/Bachelor-Kritik|title=Bologna-Prozess: Die Chance zum Kompromiss ist da|last=Nida-Rümelin|first=Julian|date=29 October 2009|work=[[Die Zeit]]|language=German|access-date=29 November 2015}}</ref>
==Entrance standards: reading, mathematics, and writing==
Demonstrated ability in reading, mathematics, and writing, as typically measured in the United States by the [[SAT]] or similar tests such as the [[ACT (test)|ACT]], have often replaced colleges' individual entrance exams, and is often required for admission to higher education.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/26/education/edlife/26guidance-t.html|title=The Other Side of 'Test Optional'|last=O'Shaughnessy|first=Lynn|date=26 July 2009|work=The New York Times|page=6|accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref> There is some question as to whether advanced mathematical skills or talent are in fact necessary for fields such as history, English, philosophy, or art.<ref name=NYT72812>{{cite news|title=Is Algebra Necessary?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/29/opinion/sunday/is-algebra-necessary.html|accessdate=July 29, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 28, 2012|author=Andrew Hacker|authorlink=Andrew Hacker}}</ref>
==Types==
===General=== The general higher education and training that takes place in a [[university]], [[college]], or [[Institute of technology]] usually includes significant [[theory|theoretical]] and abstract elements, as well as applied aspects (although limited offerings of [[internship]]s or [[Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF)|SURF]] programs attempt to provide practical applications). In contrast, the vocational higher education and training that takes place at [[vocational university|vocational universities and schools]] usually concentrates on [[practice (learning method)|practical applications]], with very little theory.
In addition, [[professional]]-level education is always included within Higher Education, and usually in [[graduate school]]s since many [[postgraduate education|postgraduate]] [[List of academic disciplines|academic disciplines]] are both vocationally, professionally, and theoretically/research oriented, such as in the [[law]], [[medicine]], [[pharmacy]], [[dentistry]], and [[veterinary medicine]]. A basic requirement for entry into these graduate-level programs is almost always a bachelor's degree, although [[alternative pathways in education|alternative means]] of obtaining entry into such programs may be available at some universities. Requirements for admission to such high-level graduate programs is extremely competitive, and admitted students are expected to perform well.
[[File:US household wealth by education.png|thumb|Mean financial wealth of U.S. families by education of the head of household, 1989-2010]] [[File:US household income by education.png|thumb|Mean income of U.S. families by education of the head of household, 1989-2010]]
When employers in any profession consider hiring a college graduate, they are looking for evidence of [[critical thinking]], [[analytical reasoning]] skills, [[teamwork]]ing skills, [[information literacy]], [[Ethics|ethical]] judgment, [[decision-making]] skills, [[Communication studies|communication skills]] (using both text and speech), [[problem solving]] skills, and a wide knowledge of liberal arts and sciences. However, most employers consider the average graduate to be more or less deficient in all of these areas.<ref>{{cite press release |last= |first= |date= 20 January 2015 |title= Employers Judge Recent Graduates Ill-Prepared for Today’s Workplace, Endorse Broad and Project-Based Learning as Best Preparation for Career Opportunity and Long-Term Success |url= http://www.aacu.org/press/press-releases/2015employerstudentsurveys |location= Washington, DC |publisher= Association of American Colleges and Universities |agency= |access-date=11 April 2017}}</ref>
In the United States, there are large differences in wages and employment associated with different degrees. Medical doctors and lawyers are generally the highest paid workers, and have among the lowest unemployment rates. Among undergraduate fields of study, science, technology, engineering, math, and business generally offer the highest wages and best chances of employment, while education, communication, and liberal arts degrees generally offer lower wages and a lower likelihood of employment.<ref name="Simkovic" /><ref>{{cite press release| title =The Economic Value of College Majors| publisher =Georgetown University| date =May 2015| url =https://cew.georgetown.edu/cew-reports/valueofcollegemajors/| accessdate =17 August 2016 }}</ref>
==== Liberal arts ==== {{Main|Liberal arts college}}
Academic areas that are included within the [[liberal arts]] include [[environmental science]], [[great books]], [[history]], [[language]]s including English, [[linguistics]], [[literature]], [[mathematics]], [[Music education|music]], [[philosophy]], [[political science]], [[psychology]], [[religious studies]], [[science]], [[sociology]] and [[Drama school|theater]].
==== Engineering ==== {{Main|Engineering college}}
Teaching engineering is teaching the application of scientific, economic, social, and practical knowledge in order to design, build, maintain, and improve structures, machines, devices, systems, materials and processes. It may encompass using insights to conceive, model and scale an appropriate solution to a problem or objective. The discipline of engineering is extremely broad, and encompasses a range of more specialized fields of engineering, each with a more specific emphasis on particular areas of technology and types of application. Engineering disciplines include [[aerospace]], [[biological]], [[Civil engineering|civil]], [[chemical]], [[Computer engineering|computer]], [[electrical]], [[Industrial engineering|industrial]], and [[Mechanical engineering|mechanical]].
====Performing arts==== {{Main|Performing arts education}}
The [[performing arts]] differ from the [[plastic arts]] or [[visual arts]], insofar as the former uses the artist's own body, face and presence as a medium; the latter uses materials such as clay, metal or paint, which can be molded or transformed to create a [[work of art]].
Performing arts institutions include [[:Category:Circus schools|circus schools]], [[Dance studio|dance schools]], [[drama school]]s and [[music school]]s.
====Plastic or visual arts==== {{Main|Art education|Art school}}
The [[plastic arts]] or [[visual arts]] are a class of [[Art#Art forms|art forms]], that involve the use of materials, that can be moulded or modulated in some way, often in three dimensions. Examples are [[painting]], [[sculpture]], and [[drawing]].
Higher educational institutions in these arts include [[film school]]s and [[List of art schools|art schools]].
===Vocational=== {{Main|Vocational university|Vocational school|Technical school}}
Higher vocational education and training takes place at the non-university tertiary level. Such education combines teaching of both practical skills and theoretical expertise. Higher education differs from other forms of post-secondary education such as that offered by institutions of [[vocational education]], which are more colloquially known as [[vocational school|trade schools]]. Higher vocational education might be contrasted with education in a usually broader [[science|scientific]] field, which might concentrate on [[theory]] and abstract [[concept]]ual knowledge.
===Professional higher education=== This describes a distinct form of higher education that offers a particularly intense integration with the world of work in all its aspects (including teaching, learning, research and governance) and at all levels of the overarching Qualifications Framework of the European Higher Education Area. Its function is to diversify learning opportunities, enhance employability, offer qualifications and stimulate innovation, for the benefit of learners and society.
The intensity of integration with the world of work (which includes enterprise, civil society and the public sector) is manifested by a strong focus on application of learning. This approach involves combining phases of work and study, a concern for employability, cooperation with employers, the use of practice-relevant knowledge and use-inspired research.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://haphe.eurashe.eu|title = Harmonising Approaches to Professional Higher Education in Europe|date = 2013|accessdate = 2014-10-17|website = Harmonising Approaches to Professional Higher Education in Europe|publisher = EURASHE|last = |first = }}</ref>
Examples of providers of professional higher education may include graduate colleges of [[architecture]], [[Business school|business]], [[Journalism school|journalism]], [[Law school|law]], [[Library school|library science]], [[optometry]], [[Pharmacy school|pharmacy]], [[Public policy school|public policy]], [[Medical school|human medicine]], [[Engineering education|professional engineering]], [[Podiatric medical school|podiatric medicine]], [[Dental school|scientific dentistry]], [[K-12 education]], and [[Veterinary school|veterinary medicine]].
===Statistics=== A report titled 'Education at a Glance 2014' published by the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] on 9 September 2014, revealed that by 2014, 84 percent of young people were completing upper secondary education over their lifetimes, in high-income countries. Tertiary-educated individuals were earning twice as much as median workers. In contrast to historical trends in education, young women were more likely to complete upper secondary education than young men. Additionally, access to education was expanding and growth in the number of people receiving university education was rising sharply. By 2014, close to 40 percent of people aged 25–34 (and around 25 percent of those aged 55–64), were being educated at university.<ref name="ReportOECD">{{cite news|title=Higher levels of education paying off for young, says OECD|url=http://www.oecd.org/edu/eag.htm |date=September 2014 |accessdate=September 11, 2014|author=[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]]}}</ref>
==Recognition of studies== The [[Lisbon Recognition Convention]] stipulates that degrees and periods of study must be recognised in all of the Signatory Parties of the Convention.
==As employers== [[File:2015-04-23 Kirylo Cope DSC0072.jpg|upright=1.1|right|thumb|University governance generally involves input from the Faculty. Here [[James D. Kirylo]], president of [[Southeastern Louisiana University]]'s [[Academic senate|Faculty Senate]] confers with Kevin L. Cope, president of the [[LSU]] Faculty Senate and president of the Association of Louisiana Faculty Senates, during a 2015 panel presentation in [[Hammond, Louisiana|Hammond]] on university funding issues for [[Fiscal Year]] 2016.]] Universities may employ a number of people. Depending on the funding, a university typically hires one teacher per 3–25 students. According to the ideal of research-university, the university teaching staff is actively involved in the research of the institution. In addition, the university usually also has dedicated research staff and a considerable support staff. Typically to work in higher education as a member of the academic [[Faculty (teaching staff)|faculty]], a candidate must first obtain a doctorate in an academic field, although some lower teaching positions require only a master's degree.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}}
Most of the administrative staff works in different administrative sections, such as [[Student Affairs]].{{citation needed|reason=This appears 'top of the head'. Really needs citation and more university 'sections'.|date=November 2011}} In addition, there may be central support units, such as a university [[library]] which have a dedicated staff.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cornell University Library Staff Web|url=http://staffweb.library.cornell.edu/|accessdate=8 January 2013}}</ref>
The professional field involving the collection, analysis, and reporting of higher education data is called [[institutional research]]. Professionals in this field can be found at locations in addition to universities, e.g. state educational departments.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}}
Post-secondary institutions also employ graduate students in various assistantship roles. In the US, close to 50% of graduate students are employed as graduate assistants at some point. These apprenticeship-like positions provide opportunities for students to gain experience in, and exposure to, professional roles in exchange for funding of their academic programs.<ref>Haley, K., Hephner LaBanc, B., & Koutas, P. (2011). New school, new job, new life: Transitions of graduate assistants in student affairs. Journal of College Orientation and Transition, 18(2), 5 - 19.</ref>
== Recent controversy == From the early 1950s to the present, more and more people in the United States have gone on to pursue degrees or certificates of higher education. However this has sparked some debate in recent years as some advocates say that a degree is not what it was once worth to employers. To clarify some advocates say that the financial costs that universities require from their students has gone up so dramatically that it is leaving many students in debt of loans of an average of $37,172<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://studentloanhero.com/student-loan-debt-statistics/|title=U.S. Student Loan Debt Statistics for 2017 {{!}} Student Loan Hero|work=Student Loan Hero|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en-US}}</ref> compared to 2000, where the average debt students graduated with was $16,928.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/03/08/college/q_studentdebt/|title=Student debt increasingly unmanagable - Mar. 8, 2002|website=money.cnn.com|access-date=2017-12-09}}</ref> In the United States there is an estimated 44 million Americans with a combined $1.3 trillion student loan debt.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2017/02/21/student-loan-debt-statistics-2017/#50c1f4f05dab|title=Student Loan Debt In 2017: A $1.3 Trillion Crisis|last=Friedman|first=Zack|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en}}</ref> Advocates advise parents to not send their children to college unless these children are committed to pursuing their future education. An increasing number of freshman every year drop out of their perspective programs or do not possess the maturity to have a balanced life away from home.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Some Career Pathways Require a Four-Year Degree, Many Don't - US News|url = https://www.usnews.com/debate-club/is-a-college-degree-still-worth-it/some-career-pathways-require-a-four-year-degree-many-dont|website = US News & World Report|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref>
However statistics from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics indicate that the college educated are employed at a rate nearly twice that of the national average when compared to high school graduates.<ref>{{Cite web|title = U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|url = http://www.bls.gov/|website = www.bls.gov|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref> The type of degree one pursues will determine how safe and prosperous his/her career path is. A study published by the Pew Charitable Trusts, shows that among Americans ages 21 to 24, the drop in employment and income was much steeper among people who lacked a college degree. "Among those whose highest degree was a high school diploma, only 55% had jobs even before the downturn, and that fell to 47% after it. For young people with an associates degree, the employment rate fell from 64 to 57. Bachelor's degree slipped from 69 to 65."<ref>{{Cite news|title = Study Shows College Degree's Value During Economic Downturn|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/10/education/study-shows-college-degrees-value-during-economic-downturn.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2013-01-09|access-date = 2015-10-11|issn = 0362-4331|first = Richard|last = Pérez-peña}}</ref> Professor Lisa Kahn of Yale stated that people who graduated from college in the most recent recession were in a position to gain better security than others.
Ultimately a survey, the Great Jobs and Great Lives Gallup-Purdue Index report <!-- (what year?) released in May --> found the type of college that students attend and in some cases even majors they choose have very little to do with their overall success and well-being later in life. What matters more, the index found, is feeling supported and making emotional connections during school.<ref>{{Cite web|title = College Grads Question How Much a Degree Is Worth|url = https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/02/10/college-grads-question-the-return-on-investment-of-todays-degrees|website = US News & World Report|date = 2015-02-10|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref>

The '''Illinois State Bar Association High School Mock Trial Invitational''' is a [[mock trial]] tournament that has been held every year since 1983. The event is co-administered by the [[Illinois State Bar Association]] and the Illinois Trial Team.<ref name="2018 ISBA">{{cite web|url=https://www.isba.org/iln/2018/03/2018highschoolmocktrialinvitational|title=2018 High School Mock Trial Invitational - Illinois State Bar Association|website=www.isba.org|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> The winning team represents the state of Illinois at the [[National High School Mock Trial Championship]]. Originally held in [[Springfield, Illinois]], the invitational moved to [[Champaign, Illinois]] in 2013. In 2018, 39 high schools participated.<ref name="2018 Thank You">{{cite web|url=https://www.isba.org/sites/default/files/teachers/mocktrial/2018%20Thank%20You%20Memo.pdf|title=2018 Thank You Memo|first=Katy|last=Karayannis|website=isba.org|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref> The defending champion is [[St. Charles North High School]].<ref name="2018 ISBA" />
==Format==
Each school must submit a roster of no more than ten members.<ref name="ISBA Registration">{{cite web|url=https://www.isba.org/sites/default/files/teachers/mocktrial/2018%20Registration%20Materials.pdf|title=ISBA Registration|website=isba.org|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> The tournament consists of two preliminary rounds, with each school having a chance to represent both the plaintiff/prosecution and defense. After the first two rounds, the eight highest scoring teams advance to a final round.<ref name="Rules">{{cite web|url=https://www.isba.org/sites/default/files/teachers/mocktrial/2018%20Mock%20Trial%20Handbook.pdf|title=ISBA Rules|website=isba.org|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> The team with the highest point total following the final round wins the tournament.

The following is a list of invitational champions:<ref name ="ISBA Past Winners">{{cite web|url=https://www.isba.org/teachers/mocktrial/pastwinners|title=Mock Trial Past Winners - Illinois State Bar Association|website=www.isba.org|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref>

The winner of the ISBA High School Mock Trial Invitational has represented the state at the [[National High School Mock Trial Championship]] since its inaugural tournament in 1984.<ref name="Nationals History">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalmocktrial.org/about/history-and-winners/|title=History and Winners - National High School Mock Trial Championship, Inc.|website=www.nationalmocktrial.org|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> No Illinois team has ever won the tournament, although [[Hinsdale Central High School]] finished in 2nd place in 2010. <ref name="Nationals History" /> Most recently, Illinois finished 27th at the 2018 National Championship in [[Reno, Nevada]].<ref name="Nationals 2018">{{cite web|url=http://www.nvmocktrial.com/wp-content/uploads/Final-Team-Results.pdf|title=2018 Championship Results|website=www.nvmocktrial.org|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref>

{{lowercase title}} {{Infobox Software | name = iSpring Suite | logo = iSpring Logo.PNG | screenshot = SuiTeRiBBoN.PnG | caption = iSpring Suite Ribbon in PowerPoint | released = {{Start date and age|2005}} | programming_language = <!-- Don't forget your source, please --> | latest_release_version = 8.3.0.15546 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2016|07|26|df=yes/no}} | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]] | genre = [[Educational software]], [[Presentation software]], [[Authoring system|Authoring tools]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] | website = {{URL|iSpringSolutions.com/ispring-suite}} }} '''iSpring Suite''' is a [[rapid learning]] [[Authoring system|authoring toolkit]] produced by iSpring for developing training courses in [[Microsoft PowerPoint|PowerPoint]] with embedded (or standalone) quizzes, surveys, and interactions. Its output is compatible with mainstream [[Learning management system|LMS]] standards ([[SCORM]]/[[Aviation Industry Computer-Based Training Committee|AICC]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Creating_SCORM_Content|title=Creating SCORM Content|work=docs.moodle.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ispringsolutions.com/articles/lms_support.html|title=LMS support|work=ispringsolutions.com}}</ref>), and there is also an option to publish courses specially for [[Blackboard Learning System|BlackBoard LMS]]. The new [[Tin Can API|xAPI (Tin Can)]] format for [[Learning Record Store|LRSes]] is supported as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tincanapi.com/adopters|title=Adopters|work=tincanapi.com/}}</ref> Output can be a solid [[SWF| SWF file(s)]], [[EXE| EXE file]], [[HTML]] page or [[Zip (file format)|ZIP]] archive. Additionally, the cross-platform output format ([[Adobe Flash|Flash]] + [[HTML5]]) allows published content to be viewed on any type of modern device.
==History== In 2005, Flashspring Pro, the prototype of all iSpring products, was released. It was a simple PowerPoint-to-Flash converter with free and commercial versions. Later, iSpring released Flashspring Ultra and [[Sharable Content Object Reference Model|SCORM]] compatibility became available. The companion products FlashSpring Lite and FlashSpring Server were released in 2006 and 2007, respectively. In 2008 the name was changed to iSpring. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.learningsolutionsmag.com/articles/745/making-sense-of-powerpoint-pandemonium|title=Making Sense of PowerPoint Pandemonium|work=learningsolutionsmag.com}}</ref>
The current version of iSpring Suite, iSpring Suite 9.0, came out in April 24th, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://elearningindustry.com/press-releases/ispring-suite-9-fast-toolkit-creating-elearning-slides-quizzes-videos|title=iSpring Suite 9: Fast Toolkit For Creating eLearning Slides, Quizzes, And Videos|work=elearningindustry.com}}</ref>
===iSpring Suite 7=== One enhancement made to iSpring Suite 7 was the support of combined, cross-platform [[Adobe Flash|Flash]] + [[HTML5]] format. It allowed users to create mobile-ready projects that adapt to any screen size and orientation.
iSpring Suite 7 came with free mobile apps for iOS<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/ispring-viewer/id642452385?mt=8|title=iSpring Viewer on the App Store on iTunes|work=[[iOS App Store]]}}</ref> and Android,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ispringsolutions.mplayer&hl=en |title=iSpring Mobile Player - Android Apps |via=[[Google Play]] }}</ref> which allow offline content viewing. The apps collect statistics on learning activity even with no Internet connection and send them to an LMS once the connection is restored.
===iSpring Suite 8=== iSpring Suite 8 introduces several new features to the toolkit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.learningsolutionsmag.com/articles/1804/ispring-suite-8-massive-new-features-not-found-in-standard-elearning-packages|title=iSpring Suite 8: Massive New Features Not Found in Standard eLearning Packages|work=learningsolutionsmag.com/}}</ref>
In version 8, a conversation simulator was added, allowing users to create simulated dialogues. Also, iSpring Suite 8 has a screen recording tool, allowing users to capture the screen and insert the recording on a PowerPoint slide, an audio/video editor both for screen recordings and audio/video narrations, and a video lecture player to show PowerPoint slides and lecture video side by side.
=== iSpring Suite 9 === Released in April 2018, the 9th version introduced 14 new interactions, a new built-in video editor with extended capabilities for screen recording, and major improvements of the quiz editor: the new [[Drag and drop|drag-and-drop]] question, the new built-in [[equation]] editor, extended feedback options, and 7 new survey question templates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.learningsolutionsmag.com/articles/toolkit-ispring-suite-9-adds-a-lot-of-great-new-features|title=Toolkit: iSpring Suite 9 Adds a Lot of Great New Features|work=learningsolutionsmag.com}}</ref>
==Features== iSpring Suite includes 5 authoring components: the iSpring add-in, iSpring QuizMaker, conversation simulator, screen recording tool and iSpring Visuals — a set of standalone tools that can be used both separately and together. Additional components available in the publishing interface are PowerPoint-to-Video/YouTube (available separately as iSpring SlideAlloy), and iSpring Cloud hosting and sharing platform.
===iSpring Converter Pro=== iSpring Converter Pro turns PowerPoint projects into mobile-ready online presentations. It supports the standard PowerPoint features such as animation, transition effects and narration facilities<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/10things/10-cool-add-ins-for-office-2007-and-2010/2455|title=10 cool add-ins for Office 2007 and 2010|work=techrepublic.com}}</ref> and contains additional features that aren't provided by PowerPoint, such as publishing to the Web or an [[Learning Management System|LMS]].
===iSpring QuizMaker=== iSpring QuizMaker allows users to create quizzes and surveys.
===iSpring Visuals=== iSpring Visuals adds rich media [[Interaction model|interactions]] to PowerPoint presentations.
===iSpring TalkMaster=== iSpring TalkMaster is a conversation simulator that allows users to create simulated dialogues for customer support training and other purposes.
===iSpring ScreenRecorder=== iSpring ScreenRecorder allows users to capture all or part of a screen and insert the recording on a PowerPoint slide, save it to MP4 video, or publish it to a YouTube account.
===iSpring SlideAlloy=== iSpring SlideAlloy converts PowerPoint presentations to videos in .mp4 format, or publishes them to YouTube.
===iSpring Cloud=== iSpring Cloud is a hosting and delivery platform for PowerPoint presentations, Microsoft documents and spreadsheets, images, video, audio, and PDF files.
==See also== *[[E-Learning]] *[[Rapid learning|Rapid E-Learning]] *[[Authoring system]] *[[List of learning management systems]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|iSpringSolutions.com}}

[[File:International Students.jpg|thumb|International students in Liechtenstein]] '''International students''' are those students who chose to undertake all or part of their tertiary education in a country other than their own and move to that country for the specific purpose of studying.<ref>{{cite wb|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20090917182725104|title=What defines and international student|publisher=University World News|date=20 September 2009|access-date=16 November 2018}}</ref> In 2016, there were nearly 5.1 million internationally mobile students (i.e. 2.3% of all tertiary students), up from 2.1 million in 2000.<ref name=UIS>{{Cite web|url=http://data.uis.unesco.org/index.aspx?queryid=169|title= Inbound internationally mobile students by continent of origin|author=[[UNESCO]] Institute for Statistics|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref> The United States and United Kingdom attracted one-third of all international students in 2000, falling to 28% in 2016.<ref name=UIS /><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|date=March 2017|title=Three waves of international student mobility (1999-2020)|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4RmnCsexL7ZckFpR1FXVFFQZ2M/view|journal=Studies in Higher Education|publisher=Taylor & Francis|volume=|pages=|doi=10.1080/03075079.2017.1293872|via=}}</ref>
==National definitions==
The definition of "foreign student" and "international student" varies in each country in accordance to their own national education system. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iie.org/Research-and-Insights/Project-Atlas/Glossary :title=Glossary|publisher=Institute of International Education|access-date=16 November 2018|date=2018}}</ref> In the US International students are "Individuals studying in the United States on a non-immigrant, temporary visa that allows for academic study at the post- secondary level. Immigrants, permanent residents, citizens, resident aliens ("Green Card" holders), and refugees are excluded from this definition."
Canada defines international students as "....temporary residents who hve been approved by an immigration officer to study in Canada. The study permit identifies the level of study and the length of time the individual may study in Canada. International students do not need a study permit for courses of six months or less if they will finish the course within the period of stay authorized upon entry, which is usually six months. Every foreign student must have a student authorization, but may also have been issued other types of permits or authorizations."{{cn|date=November 2018}}
In Australia an international student is "A student on a student visa studying in Australia with an institution registered to deliver courses to such students. Students from New Zealand are not included in the student enrolment counts as they do not require a student visa." and in Japan the definition is "A student from a foreign economy who is receiving an education at any Japanese university, graduate school, junior college, college of technology, professional training college or university preparatory course and who resides in Japan with a 'college student' visa status."{{cn|date=November 2018}}
==Destinations of foreign students== According to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) in their 2009 World Conference on Higher Education report, Over 2.5 million students were studying outside their home country. UNESCO also predicted that the number of foreign students might rise to approximately 7 million by the year 2020. The main destinations preferred were the United States, United Kingdom, Germany, France, Canada and Australia. Overall, the number of foreign students more than doubled to over 2 million between 2000 and 2007.<ref name="Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) 2010">[http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/12/9/45612617.pdf Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) 2010].</ref>
The greatest percentage increases of numbers of foreign students have occurred in New Zealand, Korea, the Netherlands, Greece, Spain, Italy and Ireland.<ref name="Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) 2010"/>
Traditionally the U.S and U.K have been the most prestigious choices, because of the presence of top 10 rankings Universities such as Harvard, Oxford, MIT and Cambridge. More recently however they have had to compete with the rapidly growing Asian higher education market. While US is the leading destination for foreign students, there is increasing competition from several destinations in East Asia such as China, Korea, Japan and Taiwan which are keen to attract foreign students for reputation and demographic reasons.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreducation.com/2017/03/Three-Waves-International-Student-Mobility-Choudaha.html|title=Three waves of international student mobility explain the past, present and future trends|website=www.dreducation.com|access-date=2017-06-04}}</ref>
Student mobility in the first decade of the 21st century has been transformed by two major external events, the attack on the New York Trade Centre and the recession of 2008.<ref name=":0" />The US to tightened visa requirements for students and Australia and the UK were successful in absorbing most of the growth in nu,mbers of foreign students. In 2009, international students represented 21.5% and 15.3% of higher education enrollment in Australia and the UK, compared to less than 4% in the US, according to the OECD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/edu/eag2011 |title=Education at a Glance |publisher=OECD |year=2011}}</ref>
According to OECD, almost one out of five foreign students is regionally mobile. This segment of regionally mobile students who seek [http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20130426103907495 global education at local cost is defined as "glocal" students]. Many "glocal" students consider pursuing transnational or cross-border education which allows them to earn a foreign credential while staying in their home countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreducation.com/2016/05/Transnational-Education-Quality-Growth-Webinar-Recording.html|title=Webinar on Transnational Education: Recording of the Online Discussion with Global Experts ~ DrEducation: Global Higher Education Research and Consulting|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|website=www.dreducation.com|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref> With the increase in tuition cost in leading destinations like the US and the UK along with the higher immigration barriers, many international students are exploring alternative destinations and demanding more "value for money."[http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20180724145334625] It is projected that the number of internationally mobile students will reach 6.9 million by 2030, an increase of 51%, or 2.3 million students, from 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20180126131034717|title=Global universities unprepared for sea change ahead|last=|first=|date=26 January 2018|website=|access-date=}}</ref>

[https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2014/11/17/number-of-international-college-students-continues-to-climb] This is changing quickly with demographic projections showing a large impending decrease in volumes of students from China and Russia and steady increases in students from India and Africa. === China === In 2016, China was the second largest receiver of international students globally, with 442,773 international students.<ref name=UIS />
==== Numbers and growth ==== [[File:International Students in China (2003-2017).png|thumb|International Students in China (2003-2017)]] The number of international students in China has grown steadily since 2003, with apparently no impact from the rise of terrorism or the 2008 global financial crisis. In contrast to the reported decline of enrollments in the USA<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/13/us/fewer-foreign-students-coming-to-us.html|title=Fewer Foreign Students Are Coming to U.S., Survey Shows|publisher=Stephanie Saul, New York Times|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref> and the UK,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2017/jan/04/anxious-international-students-turn-away-from-uk|title=Anxious international students turn away from UK|authors=Tess Reidy|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref> China's international student market continues to strengthen. China is now the leading destination globally for Anglophone African students.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/china-tops-us-and-uk-as-destination-for-anglophone-african-students-78967|title=China tops US and UK as destination for anglophone African students|publisher=Victoria Breeze, The Conversation|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
